description.narrative: Support to Livelihoods of drought affected households and resilience building of vulnerable groups in Warder and Kebridehar Woreda in Somali Region.

Output 2.1 Improved Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Productivity on 5,965 ha through introduction of climate smart technologies Indicator 2.1.1: Completely mapping of water points to facilitate sustainable use of water Indicator 2.1.2: No. of people accessing potable water from hand dug deep wells and rehabilitated water dams Indicator 2.1.3: No. of extension workers trained in rangeland resource management Indicator 2.1.4: No. of people aware of climate smart agricultural technologies Indicator 2.1.5: Area of degraded rangelands rehabilitated (ha) Indicator 2.1.6: No. of community members receiving hands-on practical feed management and utilization training disaggregated by gender
Output 2.2 Increased food security and income of 1,500 women and youth members through diversification of improved livelihoods.
Indicator 2.2.1: No. of women and youth members with new alternative livelihoods Indicator 2.2.2 : No. of people with enhanced awareness of and linked to sustainable market outlets for their products Indicator 2.2.3: No. of people benefiting from cash for work programme Indicator 2.2.4: No. of commodity based systems identified and linked with market systems involving pastoral women and youth Indicator 2.2.5: No. of drought affected women headed households received improved breeds of young stock Output 2.3. The capacity of Regional and Woreda Institutions for Climate and Disaster Risk Reduction, adaption, preparedness and response is enhanced Indicator 2.3.1: No. of community vulnerability and recovery needs assessment report produced Indicator 2.3.2: No. of Woreda DRM and Adaptation Strategies in place and implemented Indicator 2.3.3: No. of woredas that have Drought and climate resilience monitoring and evaluation plan Indicator 2.3.4: No. of time/year weather forecasting data is disseminated to relevant institutions and target communities to facilitate early action Indicator 2.3.5: No. of times/ year that woreda and rel

Output 2.1 Improved Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Productivity on 5,965 ha through introduction of climate smart technologies Indicator 2.1.1: Water points are completely mapped to facilitate decision making Indicator 2.1.2: 1, 000 people accessing potable water from hand dug deep wells and rehabilitated water dams Indicator 2.1.3: 100 extension workers trained in rangeland resource management Indicator 2.1.4: 2,000 people aware of climate smart agricultural technologies
Indicator 2.1.5: 2,983 ha of degraded rangelands rehabilitated (ha) Indicator 2.1.6: 200 community members receiving hands-on practical feed management and utilization training disaggregated by gender
Output 2.2 Increased food security and income of 1,500 women and youth members through diversification of improved livelihoods. Indicator 2.2.1: 750 women and youth members with new alternative livelihoods Indicator 2.2.2 : 200 people with enhanced awareness of and linked to sustainable market outlets for their products
Indicator 2.2.3: 150 people benefiting from cash for work programme Indicator 2.2.4: 02 commodity based systems identified and linked with market systems involving pastoral women and youth
Indicator 2.2.5: 50 drought affected women headed households received improved breeds of young stock
Output 2.3. The capacity of Regional and Woreda Institutions for Climate and Disaster Risk Reduction, adaption, preparedness and response is enhanced
Indicator 2.3.1: 01 community vulnerability and recovery needs assessment report produced Indicator 2.3.2: 01 Woreda DRM and Adaptation Strategies in place and implemented Indicator 2.3.3: 01 woreda that have Drought and climate resilience monitoring and evaluation plan Indicator 2.3.4: 01 time weather forecasting data is disseminated to relevant institutions and target communities to facilitate early action Indicator 2.3.5: 02 times/ year that woreda and relevant Regional Bureaus convene humanitarian and development partner coordination meeting Indicator 2.3.6: 01 Climatic and early warning database established, operational, and accessible for decision making Indicator 2.3.7: 01 indigenous knowledge and modern mechanisms that facilitate access to climate information

-15,406 people is accessing potable water people accessing potable water from hand dug deep wells and rehabilitated water dams
-154 extension workers trained in rangelands resources management
-2,682 people aware of and practicing climate smart agricultural technologies
- 1,186.5 hactares of degraded rangelands rehabilitated
- 325 community members receiving hands-on practical feed management and utilization training disaggregated by gender -food security and income of 11,45Women and Youth members through diversification of improved livelihoods

Output 2.1 Improved Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Productivity on 5,965 ha through introduction of climate smart technologies Indicator 2.1.1: Water points are completely mapped to facilitate decision making Indicator 2.1.2: 500 people accessing potable water from hand dug deep wells and rehabilitated water dams Indicator 2.1.3: 50 extension workers trained in rangeland resource management Indicator 2.1.4: 1,000 people aware of climate smart agricultural technologies
Indicator 2.1.5: 00 ha of degraded rangelands rehabilitated (ha) Indicator 2.1.6: 100 community members receiving hands-on practical feed management and utilization training disaggregated by gender

Indicator 2.2.1: 50 women and youth members with new alternative livelihoods Indicator 2.2.2 : 100 people with enhanced awareness of and linked to sustainable market outlets for their products

Output 2.3. The capacity of Regional and Woreda Institutions for Climate and Disaster Risk Reduction, adaption, preparedness and response is enhanced
Indicator 2.3.1: 01 community vulnerability and recovery needs assessment report produced Indicator 2.3.2: 00 Woreda DRM and Adaptation Strategies in place and implemented Indicator 2.3.3: 00 woreda that have Drought and climate resilience monitoring and evaluation plan Indicator 2.3.4: 01 time weather forecasting data is disseminated to relevant institutions and target communities to facilitate early action Indicator 2.3.5: 02 times/ year that woreda and relevant Regional Bureaus convene humanitarian and development partner coordination meeting Indicator 2.3.6: 00 Climatic and early warning database established, operational, and accessible for decision making Indicator 2.3.7: 01 indigenous knowledge and modern mechanisms that facilitate access to climate information

Output 2.1 Improved Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Productivity on 5,965 ha through introduction of climate smart technologies Indicator 2.1.1: on-going ---- Preliminary data obtained from the Bureau of water indicating the status of the water points in Kebredahar and Warder woredas Indicator 2.1.2: Not done….. However, two dams for rehabilitation were identified and rehabilitation planned to be finalized in third quarter of 2019.
Indicator 2.1.3: (None planned f0r 2018) Indicator 2.1.4: Initiated and On-going
Indicator 2.1.5: None planned…However, in preparation, site selection was undertaken for the eventual restoration of 5,965 ha of degraded rangelands with participation of communities and key actors through range reseeding, introduction of spate irrigation and area enclosures Indicator 2.1.6: Not done..planned for 2019
Output 2.2 Increased food security and income of 1,500 women and youth members through diversification of improved livelihoods. Indicator 2.2.1: 50 women and youth members with new alternative livelihoods Indicator 2.2.2 : Partly done…100 people involved in community consultations and dialogue meetings in the two woredas of warder and Kebredahar aimed at creating awareness about the key nature-based products such as incense gums, natural honey etc,..as well as climate smart agriculture for increasing livelihood options.
Indicator 2.2.3: Not planned….hence N/A Indicator 2.2.4: On-course ……Three nature-based products namely: natural incense gum, wild honey and a local plant, Cordeauxia edulis that is used for livelihoods and coping during drought were identified.
Indicator 2.2.5: None planned for 2018
Output 2.3. The capacity of Regional and Woreda Institutions for Climate and Disaster Risk Reduction, adaption, preparedness and response is enhanced
Indicator 2.3.1: Done…01 community vulnerability and recovery needs assessment report produced Indicator 2.3.2: In progress …01; Supported implementation of DRM Mitigation and adaptation plan for Keberdahar woreda
Indicator 2.3.3: None planned for 2018 Indicator 2.3.4: Not done Indicator 2.3.5: in progress…..02 meetings; with UN OCHA Somali Regional office about co-ordination mechanisms with humanitarian agencies and the other one of the Somali Durable Solutions group in which co-ordination efforts and mechanisms especially in support of IDPs. Indicator 2.3.6: Not planned in 2018 Indicator 2.3.7: 01 mechanism initiated; discussion with Universities of Jigijiga and Keberdahar on collaborative research regarding the use of indigenous knowledge to manage natural resources indigenous knowledge and modern mechanisms that facilitate access to climate information

Output 2.1 Improved Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Productivity on 5,965 ha through introduction of climate smart technologies
-500 people accessing potable water from hand dug deep wells and rehabilitated water dams
-50 extension workers trained in rangelands resources management
-2,000 people aware of and practicing climate smart agricultural technologies
- 2,982 hactares of degraded rangelands rehabilitated
- 100 community members receiving hands-on practical feed management and utilization training disaggregated by gender
Output 2.2 Increased food security and income of 1,500 women and youth members through diversification of improved livelihoods. Indicator 2.2.1: 750 women and youth members with new alternative livelihoods Indicator 2.2.2 : 200 people with enhanced awareness of and linked to sustainable market outlets for their products
Indicator 2.2.3: 150 people benefiting from cash for work programme Indicator 2.2.4: 02 commodity based systems identified and linked with market systems involving pastoral women and youth
Indicator 2.2.5: 50 drought affected women headed households received improved breeds of young stock
